module.name: ap239_product_life_cycle_support
module.name.french: Cycle de vie du produit relatif à l'AP 239
module.keywords: module, product life cycle support, integrated logistic support, maintenance

purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 specifies an application module for the representation of product life cycle support (PLCS). It provides a comprehensive capability to describe a set of products needing support and the work needed to sustain such products in an operational condition.

This part of ISO 10303 enables the creation and management through time of a set of Assured Product and Support Information (APSI) which can be used to specify and control required support activities throughout a product's life. This information is assumed to be subject to configuration change management to sustain the validity of the information as changes occur through life.

Capability is also provided to describe the resources required, provided and used to deliver support, and to record the history of the product usage, state and work done. This concept is illustrated by Figure

This part of ISO 10303 was developed to represent the data associated with major engineering assets, such as aircraft, ships or weapon systems, which may exist either as a product design, or as an actual product. purpose.p: This part of ISO 10303 combines the functionality of the following parts of ISO 10303 into a single root:
(ISO 10303-1304) specifies an application module for the representation of the state or status of a realized product.

The module may be used for recording the existance of faults on realized products, where the fault is viewed as the state which exists after a failure event. An observed state may be related to the activity that was being performed when the state was recognized. The observed state may be assessed against a state definition.
The assignment of the observed state may be justified. The module may also be used to assign a location to an identified product or product group.

The representation of the configuration of a realized product is provided by
(ISO 10303-1292).

(ISO 10303-1292) specifies an application module for the representation of information that is the authoritative source for configuration definition information, it documents the product attributes and is the placeholder for the product requirements.
The following definitions and diagram show the relationship of product definition information, product operational information and how together they form product configuration information.

Product definition information defines the product requirements, documents the product attributes and is the authoritative source for configuration definition and control. It provides the technical basis for actions taken during all product life cycle phases and for product validation and product operational information.

Product operational information is derived from the product definition information. It consists of procedures and technical information needed by operators and support personnel to operate, maintain and dispose of the product including operating procedures, security procedures, maintenance procedures, spare parts lists, and disposal methods.

(ISO 10303-1287) specifies an application module for the representation of records of completed activities, including the use of resources. It extends the capability of (10303-1307) using the module
(10303-1259) to assert that the work described has actually taken place. Capability is also provided to characterize the recorded activity, in term of who collected the information, under what circumstance; to identify the product on which work was performed, and to relate the recorded activity to the work order, work requests and work definition from which it arose. In addition, the module enables the recording of observations to capture information which is not allowed for in the definition of the work. Although much of the content of within this module relates to the use of (ISO 10303-1258), this covers only a few per cent of the total capability, most of which is achieved by use from (ISO 10303-1259) and (ISO 10303-1269).

(ISO 10303-1306) specifies an application module for the representation of tasks with the associated resources, the assignment of tasks to products and the grouping and ordering of tasks. The resource allocation, and the assignment to a product, may be qualified by a condition, a justification or a probability. Locations may be assigned to tasks and resources. A task is defined by a specification that provides the instructions for carrying out the work. The kinds of resources that may be defined for a task are:

ul.li: products, either types of product or individual products;
people, types of people, organizations, types of organization, or positions within organizations;
documents and information held as files.

purpose.p: Task specifications may be assigned to products, product breakdown elements, zones and interfaces. Conditions may be stated in terms of the state of the product, its age, its usage or any other parameter. Justifications can be related to supporting data or documents.
This module thereby enables the definition and exchange of a computer interpretable description of the work required to support a complex engineered asset throughout its service life.
The planning and scheduling of activities on individual products is out of scope.
(ISO 10303-1307) module specifies an application module for the representation of work to be performed.
This module builds on the task specification resourced module by adding:

ul.li: the capability to capture plans and schedules;
the control of work through requests and work orders.

purpose.p: Plans and schedules are together known as schemes. Schemes may have meta-data such who, when and why they were defined associated with them. Schemes may also have resources associated with them, either as a whole or with an entry within a scheme.

outscope.li: the representation of business transactions for orderings, supplying or transporting the resources needed for product support.

definition.def: the set of information, subject to configuration change management, that is established to develop and deliver support for a product in focus

the context for which a support solution definition is created
A deployment environment identifies the set of products and defines the operating and support environment to which a support solution definition applies. A deployment environment may relate to the entire product in focus, or to a subset of it. A product in focus may thus give rise to several support solution definitions, each tailored to a different deployment environment.
the complete process of specifying, designing, manufacturing, operating and supporting a product, including its final disposal
the support of a product throughout the product life cycle

def.p: a requirement for support activity on an element of the product in focus

ul.li: product fault states;
failure effect indications and diagnostic opportunities;
externally imposed damage or user abuse;
requirements for work in the physical supply chain (e.g. move, hold, issue, lift, pack, manage resources);
safety drivers (legal and others);
environmental drivers;
required operation and/or servicing tasks to be undertaken as part of the support solution.

def.p: the work required to support a group of products within a deployment environment

ul.li: identification of the deployment environment and support solution requirements for which the support solution was designed;
a listing of relevant support drivers;
justification for the support plan;
task procedures for necessary tasks;
resource models for necessary tasks;
product definition data for required resource items.
